Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Crack Repair of Irradiated Stainless Steel by Friction Stir Processing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award supports fundamental research to uncover the mechanisms of sigma phase and chromium carbide formation in friction stir processed austenitic stainless steel. An Eulerian finite element approach will be used to predict temperatures, strains, and strains rates in the stir zone so that fraction recrystallization can be predicted for different tool speeds and feed rates. The modeling work will be combined with experiments to test the hypothesis that sigma phase and chromium carbide formation can be minimized or eliminated when friction stir processing is done under conditions that avoid dynamic recrystallization. Phase identification will be performed on processed specimens by electron backscatter diffraction and by transmission electron microscopy for model validation. Hot cell experiments on irradiated stainless steel will test a second hypothesis that friction stir processing can be done without causing helium cracking in the heat affected zone of the stirred region.

This research will provide fundamental understanding of the role of recrystallization on sigma phase and chromium carbide formation in friction stir processed austenitic stainless steel. A new approach for repairing stress corrosion cracks in nuclear components will emerge from the fundamental research results. As current fusion welding processes cause helium cracking during repair of components that have been irradiated for twenty or more years, this new approach has the potential of overcoming a major technical challenge in maintaining our fleet of aging reactors, which is critical to the national energy infrastructure and the economy. Additional societal benefits include the education of students who will be prepared to contribute to the nuclear industry, and an outreach program working with high school teachers on new curriculum development, aimed at encouraging female students to pursue careers in science and engineering.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Friction stir processing (FSP) was demonstrated as a viable method for repairing cracks in 304L stainless steel.  The mechanical properties of the repaired area (stir zone) were shown to be as good, or better, than the base material in the case of the best processing parameters.  Corrosion of the stir zone was also shown to be unaffected, compared to base material, when tested for 1000hrs in 3.5% NaCl solution at room temperature.  

New understanding in material flow and microstructure evolution in friction stir welding/processing (FSWP) was achieved.  Prior work has been post-mortem, or had not accounted for tool movement during the extraction for in-situ studies.  This work clearly identified the tool deflection and its effects on microstructure evolution.  As a result, new understanding regarding the evolution of material flow, and texture and microstructure evolution was achieved.  This new understanding will help in relating the FSWP process conditions to stir zone properties.  It will also assist other investigators with process model validation. 

A steady-state finite element model was successful in predicting the peak temperatures in three locations, compared to experiment, as well as the shape of the associated temperature curves. This allowed for reasonable predictions of recrystallized grain size in three locations behind the tool pin.  Predictions of recrystallized grain size were overestimated, but the associated hardness in the stir zone was within 10% of the experimental results.

An additive method for repairing large cracks was developed and tested in 304L stainless steel.  The method involves removing the damaged area by machining and then adding back in a solid portion of 304L stainless steel or a liquid metal portion by wire feed metal gas arc welding or by some other additive method. The area to be repaired is then friction stir processed, in order to homogenize the repair material with the base material. Properties of repaired specimens were shown to be good compared to the base material.  Further development of this method could allow for repair of areas having significant damage that would be difficult to handle with FSP alone.


Last Modified: 07/30/2018
Modified by: Michael P Miles

The mechanical properties of the repaired area (stir zone) were shown to be as good, or better, than the base material in the case of the best processing parameters. Corrosion of the stir zone was also shown to be unaffected, compared to base material, when tested for 1000hrs in 3.5% NaCl solution at room temperature. Prior work has been post-mortem, or had not accounted for tool movement during the extraction for in-situ studies. This work clearly identified the tool deflection and its effects on microstructure evolution. As a result, new understanding regarding the evolution of material flow, and texture and microstructure evolution was achieved. A steady-state finite element model was successful in predicting the peak temperatures in three locations, compared to experiment, as well as the shape of the associated temperature curves. This allowed for reasonable predictions of recrystallized grain size in three locations behind the tool pin.
